title: Thursday, 27th July, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:01am

Hiya

PM11:01am

Drowning in trading statements and numbers today

PM11:02am

How many Footsie constituents reporting today?

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Feels like a dozen or more

PM11:02am

And there's some big swings out there

PM11:02am

Not least AZ

11:02 am
PM11:02am

And all of this has left the FTSE100 perfectly unchanged

PM11:02am

Brilliant

PM11:03am

Have a pic

11:02 am
PM11:03am

https://twitter.com/isamariasmith/status/890486114984656896

PM11:03am

Transgender beer

BE11:03am

..... ok?

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Yeah, just a publicity stunt

PM11:03am

But it worked, right?

BE11:04am

I guess so.

11:03 am
PM11:04am

A SCOTTISH BREWER has brewed what it’s claiming as the ‘world’s first transgender beer’.
The beer is called No Label and is by Brew Dog to celebrate the opening the brewer’s new bar in Soho in London.
The area has long been associated with the city’s LGBT community and the beer has been brewed in a manner that reflects that.

PM11:04am

http://www.thejour...m_source=shortlink

BE11:04am

Oh. Brewdog.

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Yeah

BE11:05am

The maker of publicity stunts, questionable crowdfunding prospectuses and occasionally lager.

PM11:05am

Hang on, this is old

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Sorry

BE11:05am

Aren't we all.

PM11:05am

Three year old publicity stunt

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Back on my Twitter feed thanks to Trump

PM11:06am

Let's look at stocks

undefined
11:06 am
PM11:06am

Do we go straight in on Mystic

BE11:06am

I guess we can start there, yes.

PM11:06am

https://www.invest...1707270711032555M/

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Let's see if auto pricing has demonstrable efficacy today.

PM11:06am

Huge let down

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,286, down 827.5 (-16.18%), High: 4,413, Low: 4,260, Volume: 5.92m
11:06 am
BE11:07am

Yep!

PM11:07am

The drug trials, that is. Not the autopricer

BE11:07am

That makes life easier. So, yep, the Immunicorn fails spectacularly.

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Personally disappointing as well, since I smoked 40 a day for more than 20 years...

PM11:08am

Market response has been brutal

PM11:08am

But I do wonder whether it's overdue (tho we can come to rekindled bid spec in due course...)

11:08 am
BE11:08am

It's another case of investors getting an overhyped message that could've been corrected just by talking to an oncologist, since -- as we've said repeatedly here -- IO has largely been abandoned as a useful avenue of investigation by the basic medicine folk.

BE11:09am

Investors were blind to that, though.

BE11:09am

There was a Credit Suisse survey back in June had only 15% of investors expecting a fail.

11:09 am
PM11:09am

Yes, they should have been listening to you on this Bryce

BE11:09am

We polled 33 investors to help us gauge investor expectations on the first readout of AstraZeneca’s MYSTIC trial due mid-2017.

PM11:09am

They really should

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Results were surprising with investors more bullish on the initial outcome than CS. 85% of responders saw a positive and fileable outcome as the most likely from this first readout. The most commonly expected outcome was a positive PFS readout for the combo, with a need to wait for overall survival (OS) for the mono. Interestingly, only 15% of respondents thought the combo/mono would miss on PFS and so the market be required to wait for OS data, expected at the latest in early 2018.

BE11:10am

Though the experts haven't helped in the overhype either.

BE11:10am

Take this, nearly at random, from Cowen’s Steve Scala

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Which has a BS in pharmacy from the University of Connecticut, an MS in pharmacy from Ohio State University, an MBA from Bentley College, and is a CFA charterholder.

BE11:10am

(I'm none of these things. I just talk to oncologists in the pub sometimes.)

BE11:11am

Assuming that durvalumab plus tremelimumab in MYSTIC replicate the performance of Opdivo plus Yervoy at two-years in CM-012, the probability for success in MYSTIC for PFS at the mid-’17 look is unchanged: the durvalumab plus tremelimumab combo has 99% chance to hit at PD-L1 greater than 50%.

11:11 am
PM11:11am

hehehe

BE11:11am

99% chance of success at a +50% cutoff.

BE11:12am

Turns out it failed at a +25% cutoff.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

(@littleclenches: this isn't the time or the place to go into the argument but generally, IO is capable of beating chemo in very narrow specific indications but the narrowness of those indications undermines the idea that IO will be mass market.)

PM11:14am

How about analyst reaction this morning?

PM11:14am

Have people come out with their hands up -- or just saying "we're shocked, this is bad"

11:14 am
BE11:15am

(@littleclenches: which is why the science below the current translational level that feeds into drug pipeline has abandoned IO and gone headlong into gene sequencing ... sorry, I'll stop typing in brackets now.)

BE11:15am

Well, the first sell side out of the traps have been the ones who were cautious anyway.

BE11:15am

Those with buys are doing the "but a bid, maybe?" angle.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Here's Jefferies, which is a holder so probably about the most balanced view possible.

BE11:16am

The failure of MYSTIC to hit the PFS endpoint for the mono and combo arms is a
significant blow, which we estimate removes c.10%-15% of mid term earnings
and valuation from AZN. We see no read through for BMY, though the market
is primed to make a negative correlation. We expect the market to now focus
on both the dividend cover at AZN, as well as its potential as a consolidation
target, once the MYSTIC fail is priced in.

BE11:16am

Not the end of the story, but as good as from our perspective: While the study has
failed to demonstrate a PFS benefit, it will continue to run until OS reads out, likely during
1H18. We are skeptical of MYSTIC’s ability to show an OS benefit for both mono and combo
following the PFS fails, given that it will be further confounded by cross over.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

We have modeled $5.1bn peak sales around MYSTIC, but heavily risk-adjusted:
We currently model c.$3.3bn in peak sales for durvalumab in metastatic NSCLC and c.
$1.8bn for tremelimumab, which is primarily predicated on the outcome of MYSTIC. Of
the $3.3bn durvalumab peak in metastatic NSCLC, only c.$500m is in monotherapy, with
the remaining $2.8bn assumed to be in combo use with tremelimumab. Even without final
clarification from the OS endpoints, we expect the stock to largely reflect the full failure of
MYSTIC today.

BE11:17am

Significant downside following MYSTIC headlines: Our model assumes 65% and
33% probabilities of success for the mono and combo arms of MYSTIC, respectively, with a
c.$5.1bn revenue opportunity for durvalumab and tremelimumab combined. We recently
indicated that if MYSTIC failed to meet statistical significance on the primary PFS endpoint
for the combination arm (as well as for mono) we would likely remove the full revenue
opportunity from the combo in NSCLC from our model, which in turn could reduce our
mid-term EPS estimates and valuation by c.10%-15%.

BE11:17am

Takeover speculation vs. Dividend concerns: MYSTIC has been a key component of
AstraZeneca’s long-term growth. With the failure of MYSTIC, at least on the PFS endpoints,
now likely to be fully factored into expectations, the dividend may now look less safe
and we expect some investors will start to question its long-term sustainability, despite
prior reassurances from management. However, the company still has a number of other
interesting pipelines and recently launched assets and durvalumab (Imfinzi) have already
had success in other settings (Stage III unresectable NSCLC and bladder) and could still show
benefits in other indications including head & neck, SCLC, breast and pancreatic cancer. As
a result, we would expect the stock to find some support as a potential consolidation target,
once the negative impact of MYSTIC has been priced in.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Actually, before more grey, can I ask a question?

PM11:18am

Shoot

BE11:18am

Does anyone know the sequence of events that led to AZN releasing Mystic this morning?

11:18 am
PM11:18am

??

PM11:18am

In what sense?

undefined
11:21 am
PM11:21am

We'll have to come back to the AZ sequencing

BE11:21am

..... sorry, system kicked me out while. typing.

PM11:21am

Ah, you're back!

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Back now. As I was saying ......

BE11:22am

There was a suggestion around yesterday afternoon to expect Mystic imminently ....

BE11:22am

.... which is fair enough. We'd been told to expect the results to be made public pretty much as soon as they arrived with AZN.

11:23 am
PM11:23am

Big firms are very hot on this stuff now.

PM11:23am

They know the FCA will come knocking otherwise

BE11:23am

... however... It seems odd to me that AZN also had positive data on Tagrisso and a licensing deal with Merck to send out at the same time.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Were those held back?

PM11:24am

hmm

BE11:24am

Were those seen as not price sensitive enough to announce immediately? Or is it just coincidence that we get all three at once?

11:24 am
BE11:24am

It doesn't sit quite right with me.

BE11:24am

anyway, here's Goldman.

BE11:24am

We view the MYSTIC news as a major disappointment given that this was
central to AZN’s corporate strategy. We have previously written about its
importance to AZN (MYSTIC: AZN’s biggest 2017 event; a statistical and
commercial trial, May 30). The partnership with Merck for Lynparza could
deliver some long-term benefit to AZN, if it results in closer collaboration.
However, we believe it will be interpreted as a needed partnering of a key
growth asset to sustain near-term cash flows, while the prospect of future
pipeline growth has become less likely with the MYSTIC failure. The press
release announcing MYSTIC does not comment on any trend for benefit,
and does not comment on safety, which we view as a negative. The
FLAURA results for Tagrisso are a positive, but we do not believe this is
sufficient to offset the impact of MYSTIC as company consensus Tagrisso
revenues of $2.2bn in 2020E already reflect the frontline opportunity.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

And Citi.

BE11:25am

We now view MYSTIC as essentially a failed trial and carry little hope of
positive OS benefit in 1H 2018 given cross over and other factors. We anticipate a
significant near-term negative impact to EPS and multiple as the credibility investors
were willing to attach to AZN’s broader pipeline is impacted. The reports of the
CEO’s recent alleged discussion with Teva are clearly unhelpful in light of today’s
MYSTIC news (Alert: AstraZeneca PLC (AZN.L) - Shalom Pascal? CEO Teva
bound, or maybe not). The positive news on FLAURA with Tagrisso in 1st line
NSCLC is important and welcome, and together with PACIFIC will partly offset the
earnings gap created by MYSTIC. We assume the announcement of the MRK
collaboration around Lynparza and selumetinib reflects AZN financial constraints
and AZN’s desire to dominate the PARP landscape. Our bull-bear indicated a NPV
for AZN of £40 in the event MYSTIC and NEPTUNE failed. We will review our
financial forecasts in context of today’s news, however we view the risk of market
over-reaction to today’s news as significant given we see this as essentially a trial
rather than a drug failure (at least for durvalumab). We prefer Buy-rated AZN,
Roche and Bayer in EU. We prefer Buy-rated LLY and BMY in the US.

BE11:25am

And I could go on, but won't.

11:25 am
undefined
PM11:26am

Yeah, we should rattle through some other stuff

PM11:26am

Diageo Rocket

11:26 am
PM11:26am

https://www.invest...1707270700132236M/

PM11:26am

And AB Inbev, as noted on the right

Diageo PLC (DGE:LSE): Last: 2,426, up 153.5 (+6.75%), High: 2,435, Low: 2,363, Volume: 3.65m
11:27 am
PM11:27am

These guys are benefiting from monopolistic power, in my view

PM11:27am

AB Inbev in particular

BE11:27am

For Diageo, full year's good. All of it.

11:27 am
PM11:27am

Cash rolling in

BE11:28am

Sales, profit both beat, and you get a £1.5bn share buyback on top.

BE11:28am

margin guidance to 175bp by FY19 from 100bp

11:28 am
PM11:28am

Mature businesses like this hiking margins...

BE11:29am

It's largely a premiumisation story. Crown Royal, Johnnie Walker and Tanqueray the drivers.

PM11:29am

It's what investment bankers call "attractive market structure"

11:29 am
PM11:29am

ie, monopolistic power

BE11:30am

(What is Crown Royal, incidentally? Is it American?)

PM11:30am

Canadian

11:30 am
BE11:31am

(Oh.)

PM11:01am

Welcome to our daily markets chat

BE11:31am

First impressions:
· F17 results are ahead of company consensus. Although OSG was in-line, organic EBIT at +5.6% was ahead of consensus at +5.1% and was supported by organic margin expansion +37bps in the period. This left Clean EPS +2.8% ahead of consensus;
· Against this backdrop, management are increasing their productivity savings target to £700m by end FY19E (from £500m). Although two-thirds of this is still expected to be reinvested back into the business, it does mean the group now expects margins to increase +175bps over the three year period to end of FY19E. Separately, with net debt/EBITDA at 2.0x, the Board has approved a £1.5bn share buyback programme to be implemented in F18;
· Divisionally, F17 trading was mixed with North America disappointing, as US spirits sales grew just +3% in the year (Ciroc and Ketel One came under pressure). Elsewhere profitability was better in Europe, Asia and Africa;
· In our view, the new Chairman at Diageo is clearly making his presence felt. Despite tougher trading in the group’s core US business, the long-hoped for raise to the group’s productivity savings plan should be taken well by investors and underpin LSD mid-term estimate upgrades. Moreover, with this accompanied by a long-awaited new share buyback programme, we expect the shares to enjoy some support today.

11:31 am
PM11:31am

Best selling Canadian whisky in the US, actually. You see it on shows like Nashville

BE11:31am

Canadian whisky? Well I never.

BE11:32am

I guess it has a novelty value, like English wine and transgender beer.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Cazenove, off the conference call.

BE11:33am

Diageo’s FY17 results call was unsurprisingly confident with acceleration expected across all fronts in FY18E. Our key takeaways were 1. Diageo expects US growth to accelerate in FY18 (post 3.4% in F17) with plans to improve trends in Ketel One and Ciroc. US shipments and depletions growth is currently at 3% for DGE versus 4% for the industry. 2. Scotch growth of MSD in FY18E is expected to more balanced growth between volume, price and mix versus volume bias in FY17. 3. In India the GST impact is not as severe as initially anticipated though Diageo does expect an adverse margin impact in FY18. 4. On cost savings Diageo is very confident it will achieve the increased guidance based on benchmarking across CPG and other industries. Remaining 135bps for FY18 and FY19 will be skewed to FY19 given cost required to achieve (not accounted for as exceptional). Total reinvestment of c.£470m (2/3rds) will primarily be in the US and Scotch globally. 5. Buyback of £1.5bn keeps Diageo below adjusted net debt to EBITDA target range of 2.5x-3x leaving headroom for further M&A in spirits as well as non-alcoholic beverages.

undefined
11:34 am
PM11:34am

Too many trading statements

PM11:34am

All ive done this morning is skim read

BE11:34am

And a few grifty stories mentioned on the right, which didn't really merit more than a skim read either.

11:35 am
Unilever PLC (ULVR:LSE): Last: 4,367, up 10.5 (+0.24%), High: 4,397, Low: 4,335, Volume: 406.38k
BE11:35am

.... for instance.

BE11:36am

"Bankers" pushing Unilever's board to bid for Colgate while conditions are "ripe", reports Streetinsider.

11:36 am
PM11:36am

right

BE11:36am

You'll remember the noise around Colgate back in May that the CEO would be okay with someone bidding $100 a share

BE11:37am

New York Post story, extremely flaky.

11:37 am
PM11:37am

Yeah

PM11:37am

So this is a re-heat

BE11:37am

And Unilever is of course the most obvious buyer of Colgate, now Reckitt's tied itself up with baby powder.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

So, yes, I'm sure bankers with fees connected to the eventual sale of Colgate have been pushing Unilever to bid.

undefined
PM11:38am

Can we revisit your idea that Murdoch doesnt really want Sky?

11:38 am
BE11:39am

Certainly!

PM11:39am

Figs this morning were pretty unimpressive

PM11:39am

But you know how Sky has been such a terrific performer over the past three years?

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Hm.

PM11:40am

You know, whole business humming along...

PM11:40am

Which has triggered this...

11:41 am
PM11:41am

LTIP awards granted to the Executive Directors in 2014 and 2015 for the three year performance period ended 30 June 2017 have now vested in full. The Executive Directors give notice that they intend to exercise up to all of the vested awards and sell the resulting shares. This is consistent with their previous practice.

PM11:41am

And ... more to your theory about Murdoch

PM11:41am

Accordingly, Jeremy Darroch gives notice that he intends to exercise awards over and sell up to 1,200,000 Ordinary Shares and Andrew Griffith gives notice that he intends to exercise awards over and sell up to 700,000 Ordinary Shares.

11:42 am
PM11:42am

Darroch taking £11.6m off the table

PM11:43am

Have as bit of Liberum

PM11:43am

KPI weakness likely to be the focus

11:43 am
PM11:43am

While the adjusted EPS beat at 61.3p vs consensus 57.9p, the KPIs do not look good at all. Sky only added 35K new customers in the UK and Ireland in Q4, a sharp drop from last year's Q4 93K and even below the seasonally quiet Q3 number. Churn in the UK has also risen again to 11.5% (from 11.2% for FY16) and there has been a sharp increase in Germany (12.6% for FY vs 9.9% in FY16). ARPU continues to stagnate in the UK, despite price increases, at £47 while it has actually fallen in Germany (€34 from €35).

PM11:44am

That Fox bid better come through...

BE11:44am

Hmmm ..... I mean, the results aren't a disaster. The problems in Italy (where subs went negative) can be blamed on a dispute with Telecom Italia .....

11:44 am
BE11:44am

...... churn, ARPU in Germany clearly a worry

BE11:45am

What I'd note is that there's a £200m break fee, so my guess is that trading would have to deteriorate quite a bit more before Murdoch sees the deal as unpalatable.

BE11:46am

Though there's plenty of time for that to happen, with an EPL rights auction in the middle as well.

11:46 am
undefined
PM11:46am

What else has caught your eye?

BE11:47am

Hm ........

11:47 am
PM11:48am

Foxtons?

PM11:48am

oh dear

BE11:48am

Yes, okay, Foxtons.

11:48 am
PM11:48am

Sorry interims here https://www.invest...1707270700032108M/

Foxtons Group PLC (FOXT:LSE): Last: 91.75, down 4.25 (-4.43%), High: 94.25, Low: 89.25, Volume: 463.14k
PM11:48am

DIvi slashed

11:49 am
PM11:49am

Business looks to be grinding to a halt

BE11:49am

Not unexpectedly, though the argument with Foxtons was always that it had spare cash to cover the divi even in that eventuality.

PM11:50am

Matches all the anecdotal evidence of the London property market seizing up

11:50 am
BE11:50am

London volumes down by a third!

BE11:51am

Dumb question ... why are London volumes down by a third?

PM11:51am

Generalised Brexit uncertainty, no?

11:51 am
PM11:51am

Simple as that

BE11:52am

I thought there was the stalling effect around Brexit, but why's it continued when we should be looping that on a YOY basis?

BE11:52am

Do people not move house any more?

11:52 am
BE11:53am

I figured the ROTR would have views, largely pinned on the idea of a house being an illiquid investment rather than a necessity to keep the rain out.

BE11:53am

Have some Peel Hunt.

BE11:53am

The London sales market has remained challenging and has
weighed significantly on first-half profits, with EBITDA 46%
lower than the prior year. Of course, operational gearing works
in both directions, but we see no near-term catalyst for an
improvement in trading and have reduced our FY17 PBT by
c35% and halved our dividend forecast to 1p. From 2018, the
group will face a further headwind from the lettings fee ban. On
revised numbers the shares trade on an FY17 PE of c35x. We
have reduced our target price to 60p and retain our Sell
recommendation.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

35x. Super.

PM11:54am

Crazy

BE11:54am

And Numis.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Foxtons' H1 results show the impact of a challenging London sales market which has become more difficult post the recent General Election. This reduction in activity has prompted a further reduction in estimates, but we are encouraged by a resilient performance in Lettings and managements cost saving activities. Whilst there is no sign of the sales market improving, we think this low level of activity cannot persist for a extended period of time and when conditions do improve Foxtons is well placed to benefit given strong listing volumes.

BE11:55am

H1 EBITDA of £7.1m is down 46% on last year – versus our provisional estimate of
£8.8m. This partly reflects the strong Q1 performance in 2016 (due to brought forward
property transactions ahead of the change to stamp duty on second homes) but also
that the London sales market has remained difficult on an underlying basis, with the
election adding to already high levels of uncertainty. Based on the weakening trends
seen toward the end of June and in early July (which has impacted the pipeline of deals)
we are reducing full year 2017 EBITDA from £20m to £15m and 2018 from £21.3m to
£15m. The lower profit alongside some caution relating to the potential ban on tenant
fees (which is not yet included in profit estimates - but could be a £4/5m hit) has led us
to reduce our 2017/18 dividend estimate from 4.5p/5.1p to 2p in both years.

BE11:55am

Clearly it is disappointing to reduce estimates again, but we think this reflects market
trends and the group has put in a resilient performance on cost savings (costs reduced
£3.7m in H1 despite some one-off costs and the addition of two more branches in H1)
and volume growth in Lettings has broadly offset a reduction in rental rates. Looking
into the second half of the year, we expect the sales market to remain depressed in the
absence of a catalyst, but an expected flattish performance in Lettings in Q3 should
help the group deliver a similar profit performance to H1. Based on these trends and
our new dividend forecasts we expect Foxtons to end 2017 with increased net cash.
● Importantly we believe that the level of Foxtons listings has remained strong in the
period and is broadly flat on last year, meaning that when confidence returns to the
market it is well placed to capitalise and show high levels of operational gearing. Given
the depressed nature of revenue/profits, Foxtons is trading on a high earnings multiple
(c.39x PE for 2017), but on any normalised analysis the shares continue to look cheap.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

... which I don't think is a bad argument. You should be valuing Foxtons as if it were in a normalised market, because it will be sometime.

PM11:57am

Sometime feels a long way away at the moment

BE11:57am

Valuing Foxtons as if it were in a normalised market would seem to require a clearer view on why the market's currently abnormal, and I'm not 100% convinced by any of the reasons put forward on either side of the page.

11:58 am
PM11:58am

It's become impossible for people to move up the property ladder, of course

PM11:58am

In the traditional sense

PM11:59am

Getting a raise or a better paid job doesnt allow people to make the leap from a 2 bed flat to a house, say

11:59 am
PM11:59am

London will never again be "normal"

PM11:59am

Unless something very extreme happens

undefined
12:00 pm
PM12:00pm

I should tell you on the right that Bryce has been kicked out of the system again

PM12:00pm

Dunno what's going on

PM12:00pm

Tech as maddening as ever

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

I'm back now. I'm on a Mac so can't diagnose the problem, because it's a Mac.

BE12:01pm

The software thinks it's cleverer than me. It's right, of course, but it's still a tad frustrating.

BE12:01pm

Anyway, do we have anything else to note?

12:01 pm
PM12:01pm

There's loads of stuff we havent touched

PM12:02pm

But the hour is up

PM12:02pm

Can we squeeze in some Lloyds?

12:02 pm
PM12:02pm

Perhaps

PM12:02pm

Have Trader Gordon

BE12:02pm

Sure. PPI lingers on.

12:02 pm
PM12:02pm

A mix of issues, but we welcome these consensus-busting Q2 2017 numbers and improved guidance. U/L PBT is a 20% “beat” against us and 24% ahead of consensus, or 13/17% ex-Vocalink gain (£146m). As ever, the key areas where consensus remains stubbornly adrift are NIM and impairments. NIM rose by 2bp QoQ to 2.82% in Q2 2017 while consensus modelled a decline to 2.77%. The H1 impairment charge collapsed to just 12bps. Fresh upgrades beckon. BUY.

PM12:03pm

He's such a fan

PM12:03pm

U/L PBT was £2.4bn in Q2 2017, a £473m (24%) u/l PBT beat vs company-compiled consensus with revenues, £426m (10%) ahead, and impairments £120m (46%) better. Costs were a £73m (3%) miss, (see table 1, page 2).
“Below the line” drag is still receding, but even so, relative to our/consensus expectations it offers “negative surprise” in the quarter. PPI top-up is £0.7bn, cumulative charge of £18.1bn (see Fig 3, page 4) which we see (in part) as a “pull-forward” of already expected further charges. “Other Conduct” is £340m.
As expected, tNAV per share declines QoQ (reflecting the 2016 dividend and MBNA completion) but the 4.1p QoQ drop to 52.4p is exacerbated by one-offs.
CET1 ratio is 13.5%. Capital generation in H1 2017 was 100bps and is still guided towards c.200bps for the full-year, underpinning our dividend forecasts.
We do not argue that Lloyds is an “exciting” growth story. In balance sheet terms it most certainly isn’t (see Fig 1, page 3). But (for us) that’s not the point. With a largely stable underlying profit before tax and declining net negative exceptional items, we are already seeing sharply higher reported earnings, (see Fig 2, page 3) which creates materially increased dividend capacity (see Fig 4, page 4).
The Interim Dividend was increased by 0.15p (18%) to 1.0p. After 3.05p in 2016 we still forecast 4.5-5.5p through 2017-2019e; an implied yield of 6.5-8.0%.
Beats on NIM and impairments should drive material new consensus upgrades. Buy rec & 75p TP reaffirmed; the finer detail of forecasts is now under review.

12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

But the stock is off 2 per cent now

BE12:04pm

I mean, fair enough. NIM and guidance raised. But it's still a mess of one-offs.

PM12:04pm

Yeah, Sandy Chen makes that point

12:04 pm
PM12:04pm

The usual caveats apply: £4.5bn in underlying pbt doesn’t include £1.1bn in PPI top-ups (£0.7bn in Q2/17) nor £0.5bn in other conduct provisions (£0.3bn in Q2/17) – including an estimated £283m for redress payments for mortgage arrears misconduct. Tangible NAVPS dipped 2.4p to 52.4p in 1H/17.

The other major gap between underlying and statutory pbt is in net interest income (£5.2bn statutory vs £5.9bn underlying). As outlined in our 5 July note, we think a significant portion of this gap can be accounted for by the “Certainty Equivalent” approach that Lloyds uses to smooth its Insurance division results – and that the “real” net interest income is closer to the £5.2bn statutory. Unfortunately, we won’t know what “real” net interest income is until the advent of IFRS17 insurance accounting rules in 2021, but we still think it’s relevant when considering the slightly upgraded underlying net interest margin guidance (to 285bp including the MBNA credit card acquisition, from c.280p without).

A CET1 ratio of 13.5% (end-16: 13.8%) is strong, but not strong enough to justify hopes of big special dividends. The interim dividend of 1.0p (up 18%) is enough of a drain on 2.0p of statutory EPS (down 13%) already.

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

NII/NIM ahead
NII increased 4%yoy in Q2, a 2% beat versus consensus. Banking NIM in the quarter was 2.83% and new guidance for LLOY of 2.85% banking NIM including
MBNA (old guidance was 2.8% ex MBNA) and compares to 2.83% in consensus. Loan growth is negative ex MBNA down 1% since the end of 2016 but the
open mortgage book is flat in line with guidance and LLOY guides to slight growth in H2. Consumer finance loan growth ex MBNA is 11%yoy, continuing at the
same pace with no sign of a slowdown currently.
Other operating income significantly better than consensus
OOI increased 15%yoy in Q2, a 25% beat versus consensus. Ex the £146m vocalink gain the beat is 15% versus consensus. The strong growth is driven by
commercial banking up 12%hoh and consumer finance up 15%hoh helped by strong performance in Lex autolease.
Costs slightly worse than consensus
Costs increased 1%yoy in Q2, 3% worse than consensus. The cost income ratio at 47.6% is lower than the 49.9% in Q1. LLOY has delivered £1.2bn of run
rate savings through the Simplification programme on track to deliver £1.4bn by end 2017.
Loan loss upgrade - no sign of consumer credit stress
Impairments increased 47%yoy (11%qoq), 46% better than consensus. Cost of risk in the quarter is 13bps compared to 12bps in Q1. Guidance on cost of risk
has been upgraded to now be less than 20bps including MBNA (previously was less than 20bps ex MBNA). Consensus currently has 23bps for 2017 so it
implies some upgrades from this source. Worth noting in the consumer finance division, cost of risk is falling (67bps in H1 from 88bps at H2 2016) and impaired
loans are falling as well (1.8% versus 2.1% at end 2016) - there is no sign of consumer credit related stress in the results.
Capital a miss due to one offs, but no cause for concern
The capital ratio at 13.5% is below our expectation of 13.9% and the difference is entirely due to higher than expected one offs in Q2. There was £1bn of
conduct charges in Q2, £700m due to a PPI top up which we had not expected, and compares to £200m that we expected. With £2.6bn in unutilised PPI
provision we expect that the top up should cover all future claims to the timebar in 2019. LLOY maintains guidance for the upper end of 170-200bps capital
generation in 2017 and generated 100bps in H1 so still looks on track to hit this. The capital target is maintained at 13% despite the increase in the CCyB by
the BOE so consensus at 13.4% post dividend has some buffer in to the reaffirmed target.
